    • Method Detail

      • subject

        public FluentEmailAssert<P> subject(org.hamcrest.Matcher<? super String> matcher)
        Make assertions on the subject of the message(s). 
         .receivedMessages().message(0)
    .subject(is("foobar"))
        Will check if the subject of the first message is exactly "foobar". 
         .receivedMessages().every()
    .subject(is("foobar"))
        Will check that the subject of every message is exactly "foobar".
        Parameters:
        matcher - the assertion to apply on subject
        Returns:
        the fluent API for chaining assertions on received message(s)

      • body

        public FluentPartAssert<FluentEmailAssert<P>> body()
        Make assertions on the body of the message(s) using fluent API. The body of the message is either:
        • The part of the message when it contains only one part
        • The part with text or HTML mimetype if only one part with one of that mimetype
        • The second part with text or HTML mimetype if there are two text or HTML parts
         .receivedMessages().message(0).body()
    .contentAsString(is("email body"))
    .contentType(is("text/plain"))
        Will check if the body content of the first message is "email body" and content-type of the first message is "text/plain". 
         .receivedMessages().every().body()
    .contentAsString(is("email body"))
    .contentType(is("text/plain"))
        Will check that the body content of every message is "email body" and content-type of every message is "text/plain".
        Returns:
        the fluent API for chaining assertions on received message(s)

      • alternative

        public FluentPartAssert<FluentEmailAssert<P>> alternative()
        Make assertions on the alternative part of the message(s) using fluent API. The alternative is useful when sending HTML email that may be unreadable on some email clients. For example, a smartphone will display the 2 or 3 first lines as a summary. Many smartphones will take the HTML message as-is and will display HTML tags instead of content of email. Alternative is used to provide a textual visualization of the message that will be readable by any system.

        The alternative of the message is either:

        • null if there is only one part
        • null if there is only one text or HTML part
        • the first part if there are more than one text or HTML part
         .receivedMessages().message(0).alternative()
    .contentAsString(is("email alternative"))
    .contentType(is("text/plain"))
        Will check if the body content of the first message is "email alternative" and content-type of the first message is "text/plain". 
         .receivedMessages().every().alternative()
    .contentAsString(is("email alternative"))
    .contentType(is("text/plain"))
        Will check that the body content of every message is "email alternative" and content-type of every message is "text/plain".
        Returns:
        the fluent API for chaining assertions on received message(s)

      • body

        public <T extends javax.mail.Part> FluentEmailAssert<P> body(org.hamcrest.Matcher<? super javax.mail.Part> matcher)
        Make assertions on the body of the message(s). The body of the message is either:
        • The part of the message when it contains only one part
        • The part with text or HTML mimetype if only one part with one of that mimetype
        • The second part with text or HTML mimetype if there are two text or HTML parts
         .receivedMessages().message(0)
    .body(allOf(notNullValue(), instanceOf(MimeBodyPart.class))
        Will check if the body of the first message is not null and is a MimeBodyPart instance. 
         .receivedMessages().every()
    .body(allOf(notNullValue(), instanceOf(MimeBodyPart.class))
        Will check that the body of every message is not null and is a MimeBodyPart instance.

        You can use the body() variant to make more powerful assertions.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type used for the matcher
        Parameters:
        matcher - the assertion to apply on body
        Returns:
        the fluent API for chaining assertions on received message(s)

      • alternative

        public <T extends javax.mail.Part> FluentEmailAssert<P> alternative(org.hamcrest.Matcher<? super javax.mail.Part> matcher)
        Make assertions on the alternative part of the message(s). The alternative is useful when sending HTML email that may be unreadable on some email clients. For example, a smartphone will display the 2 or 3 first lines as a summary. Many smartphones will take the HTML message as-is and will display HTML tags instead of content of email. Alternative is used to provide a textual visualization of the message that will be readable by any system.

        The alternative of the message is either:

        • null if there is only one part
        • null if there is only one text or HTML part
        • the first part if there are more than one text or HTML part
         .receivedMessages().message(0)
    .alternative(allOf(notNullValue(), instanceOf(MimeBodyPart.class))
        Will check if the alternative of the first message is not null and is a MimeBodyPart instance. 
         .receivedMessages().every()
    .alternative(allOf(notNullValue(), instanceOf(MimeBodyPart.class))
        Will check that the alternative of every message is not null and is a MimeBodyPart instance.

        You can use the alternative() variant to make more powerful assertions.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type used for the matcher
        Parameters:
        matcher - the assertion to apply on alternative
        Returns:
        the fluent API for chaining assertions on received message(s)

      • from

        public FluentAddressListAssert<FluentEmailAssert<P>> from()
        Make assertions on the sender of the message(s) using fluent API. 
         .receivedMessages().message(0).from()
    .address(hasItems("noreply@sii.fr"))
    .personal(hasItems("Groupe SII"))
        Will check if the sender email address of the first message is exactly "noreply@sii.fr" and sender displayed address of the first message is exactly "Groupe SII". 
         .receivedMessages().every().from()
    .address(hasItems("noreply@sii.fr"))
    .personal(hasItems("Groupe SII"))
        Will check if the sender email address of every message is exactly "noreply@sii.fr" and sender displayed address of every message is exactly "Groupe SII".
        Returns:
        the fluent API for chaining assertions on received message(s)

      • to

        public FluentAddressListAssert<FluentEmailAssert<P>> to()
        Make assertions on the sender of the message(s) using fluent API. 
         .receivedMessages().message(0).to()
    .address(hasItems("recipient1@sii.fr", "recipient2@sii.fr"))
    .personal(hasItems("Foo", "Bar"))
        Will check if the list of email addresses of direct recipients (TO) of the first message are exactly "recipient1@sii.fr", "recipient2@sii.fr" and the list of displayed address of direct recipients (TO) of the first message are exactly "Foo", "Bar". 
         .receivedMessages().every().to()
    .address(hasItems("recipient1@sii.fr", "recipient2@sii.fr"))
    .personal(hasItems("Foo", "Bar"))
        Will check if the list of email addresses of direct recipients (TO) of every message are exactly "recipient1@sii.fr", "recipient2@sii.fr" and the list of displayed address of direct recipients (TO) of every message are exactly "Foo", "Bar".
        Returns:
        the fluent API for chaining assertions on received message(s)

        public FluentAddressListAssert<FluentEmailAssert<P>> cc()
        Make assertions on the sender of the message(s) using fluent API. 
         .receivedMessages().message(0).cc()
    .address(hasItems("recipient1@sii.fr", "recipient2@sii.fr"))
    .personal(hasItems("Foo", "Bar"))
        Will check if the list of email addresses of copy recipients (CC) of the first message are exactly "recipient1@sii.fr", "recipient2@sii.fr" and the list of displayed address of copy recipients (CC) of the first message are exactly "Foo", "Bar". 
         .receivedMessages().every().cc()
    .address(hasItems("recipient1@sii.fr", "recipient2@sii.fr"))
    .personal(hasItems("Foo", "Bar"))
        Will check if the list of email addresses of copy recipients (CC) of every message are exactly "recipient1@sii.fr", "recipient2@sii.fr" and the list of displayed address of copy recipients (CC) of every message are exactly "Foo", "Bar".
        Returns:

      • attachments

        public <T extends Collection<? extends javax.mail.BodyPart>> FluentEmailAssert<P> attachments(org.hamcrest.Matcher<? super Collection<? extends javax.mail.BodyPart>> matcher)
        Make assertions on the list of attachments of the message(s). 
         .receivedMessages().message(0)
    .attachments(hasSize(1))
        Will check if the number of attachments of the first message is exactly 1. 
         .receivedMessages().every()
    .attachments(hasSize(1))
        Will check that the number of attachments of every message is exactly 1.

        You can use the attachment(String) or attachments(Predicate) variants to make more powerful assertions on a particular attachment.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type used for the matcher
        Parameters:
        matcher - the assertion to apply on list of attachments
        Returns:
        the fluent API for chaining assertions on received message(s)

      • attachment

        public FluentPartAssert<FluentEmailAssert<P>> attachment(String filename)
        Make assertions on a particular attachment of the message(s) using fluent API. The attachment is identified by its filename. 
         .receivedMessages().message(0).attachment("foo.pdf")
    .contentType(is("application/pdf"))
        Will check if the content-type of the attachment named "foo.pdf" of the first message is exactly "application/pdf". 
         .receivedMessages().every().attachment("foo.pdf")
    .contentType(is("application/pdf"))
        Will check that the content-type of attachment named "foo.pdf" of every message is exactly "application/pdf".

        This is a shortcut to attachments(Predicate) with FileNamePredicate;

        Parameters:
        filename - the name of the attachment to make assertions on it
        Returns:
        the fluent API for chaining assertions on received message(s)

      • attachment

        public FluentPartAssert<FluentEmailAssert<P>> attachment(int index)
        Make assertions on a particular attachment of the message(s). 
         .receivedMessages().message(0).attachment(0)
    .contentType(is("application/pdf"))
        Will check if the content-type of the first attachment of the first message is exactly "application/pdf". 
         .receivedMessages().every().attachment(0)
    .contentType(is("application/pdf"))
        Will check if the content-type of the first attachment of every message is exactly "application/pdf".
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the attachment
        Returns:
        the fluent API for chaining assertions on received message(s)

      • attachment

        public FluentPartAssert<FluentEmailAssert<P>> attachment(By by)
        Make assertions on a particular attachment of the message(s) using fluent API. The attachment is identified using the provided finder method.

        If several attachments are found, it fails. If you want to make the same assertions on several attachments at once, use attachments(By) instead. 

         .receivedMessages().message(0).attachment(By.filename("foo.pdf"))
    .contentType(is("application/pdf"))
        Will check if the content-type of the attachment named "foo.pdf" of the first message is exactly "application/pdf". 
         .receivedMessages().every().attachment(By.filename("foo.pdf"))
    .contentType(is("application/pdf"))
        Will check that the content-type of attachment named "foo.pdf" of every message is exactly "application/pdf".

        This is a shortcut to attachments(Predicate) with FileNamePredicate;

        Parameters:
        by - the finder method
        Returns:
        the fluent API for chaining assertions on received message(s)

      • attachments

        public FluentPartAssert<FluentEmailAssert<P>> attachments(By by)
        Make assertions on a one or several attachments of the message(s) using fluent API. The attachments are identified using provided finder method. 
         .receivedMessages().message(0)
    .attachments(By.contentId("cid2")).filename(endsWith(".pdf"))
        Will check if every attachment that have the Content-ID header set to "cid2" of first message has a name ending with ".pdf". 
         .receivedMessages().every()
    .attachments(By.contentId("cid2")).filename(endsWith(".pdf"))
        Will check if every attachment that have the Content-ID header set to "cid2" of every messages has a name ending with ".pdf".
        Parameters:
        by - the finder method
        Returns:
        the fluent API for chaining assertions on received message(s)

      • attachments

        public FluentPartAssert<FluentEmailAssert<P>> attachments(Predicate<javax.mail.Part> filter)
        Make assertions on a one or several attachments of the message(s) using fluent API. The attachments are identified using provided predicate. 
         .receivedMessages().message(0)
    .attachments(new PdfFilter()).filename(endsWith(".pdf"))
        Will check if the name of every PDF attachments of the first message are named "foo.pdf". 
         .receivedMessages().every()
    .attachments(new PdfFilter()).filename(endsWith(".pdf"))
        Will check if the name of every PDF attachments of every message are named "foo.pdf".
        Parameters:
        filter - the filter used to find attachments
        Returns:
        the fluent API for chaining assertions on received message(s)
